Posts.Content: Mar 8, 2011 06:49PM - edited Mar 8, 2011 06:51PM by satisfied_survivor I had a DMX a little over a year ago.  I had implants during the intial surgery so it may have been different for me.  I felt like there was a tremendous weight on my chest for the first 4 -5  days.  I transitioned from NORCO fulltime to a triple dose of Aleve 3 times a day with half a NORCO midmorning and at bedtime on Day 7.  Ice packs brought me a lot of relief whenever I felt really uncomfortable.  It is worth a try at least.  The discomfort did taper off beginning on about day 5 and got better daily depending on how active.I was.  The more active I was,  the more discomfort I had.  Riding in the car was the worst during the first 2-3 weeks.  Carried my ice packs with me when I was riding in the car for any distance. But I was back at work fulltime at the end of 4 weeks so I think that wasn't bad considering what my body had been through.  I am not a young woman, but I do have a failry high pain threshold.

Posts.Content: Mar 18, 2011 10:51PM satisfied_survivor wrote: I know how you feel.  I made myself a nervous wreck waiting for my bilat M.  Surgery could not happen soon enough for me.  I just wanted the cancer out of my body.  I weighed only 111.1 lbs the evening of my surgery.  The RN suggested my family buy lottery tickets!  I won the lottery without a ticket having no positive nodes.  I didn't have to do chemo, but from what I have seen with friends, I'd do surgery again in a heartbeat,  I was out of the hospital in 48 hours. Drains out on day 6, path report day 7  and  back to work full time in 4 weeks. After the first 6 days I was on Aleve. I had simultaneous reconstruction so don't know how that effects things for sure.   Ice packs were most helpful and brought great relief when I felt uncomfortable. I think you will do fine.  The waiting was mentally much harder for me than the actual surgery and recovery.  Post surgery, I knew that every day was one day closer to a normal life.  Best of luck!  Anticipation and apprehension are far more stressful than surgery!

Posts.Content: Mar 18, 2011 11:15PM satisfied_survivor wrote: Realize by now that you have had your surgery.  Whatever you decided, have confidence that it will be fine.  I had immediate reconstruction and just stayed the size I was.  I have been extremely happy.  No one would ever suspect that these girls are not the ones I was born with.  My clothes all still fit, no repeated trips for fills or a second surgery.  If I were younger I might have made a different choice, but  I am  happy with the one I made.  My recovery was quick and uneventful and fortunately without chemo or radiation because I found it so early!  It was self-diagnosed Paget's. confirmed by biopsy somen 5 months later.  The mammo tech suggested  I see a dermatologist,  Fortunately I trusted my instincts instead!  I an close to 18 months post BMX and so far cancer free.
